review.title: Solving DCOPs with Distributed Large Neighborhood Search
review.abstract: The field of Distributed Constraint Optimization has gained momentum in recent years, thanks to its ability to address various applications related to multi-agent cooperation. Nevertheless, solving Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs) optimally is NP-hard. Therefore, in large-scale, complex applications, incomplete DCOP algorithms are necessary. Current incomplete DCOP algorithms suffer of one or more of the following limitations: they (a) find local minima without providing quality guarantees; (b) provide loose quality assessment; or (c) are unable to benefit from the structure of the problem, such as domain-dependent knowledge and hard constraints. Therefore, capitalizing on strategies from the centralized constraint solving community, we propose a Distributed Large Neighborhood Search (D-LNS) framework to solve DCOPs. The proposed framework (with its novel repair phase) provides guarantees on solution quality, refining upper and lower bounds during the iterative process, and can exploit domain-dependent structures. Our experimental results show that D-LNS outperforms other incomplete DCOP algorithms on both structured and unstructured problem instances.

metadata.title: Solving DCOPs with Distributed Large Neighborhood Search

sections.heading: 3 The D-LNS Framework
sections.text: In this section, we introduce D-LNS, a general distributed LNS framework for solving DCOPs. Our D-LNS solutions must take into account factors critical to distributed system performance, such as network load (i.e., number and size of messages exchanged by agents) and the limitation that each agent only knows its local subproblem (i.e., its neighbors and the constraints the scope of its variables encompasses). Such properties make typical centralized LNS techniques inappropriate and unworkable for DCOPs. Algorithm 1 shows the general structure of D-LNS as executed by each agent. After initializing its iteration counter (line 1), its current value is mapped to x0i.

sections.heading: 4.1 DPOP-based DBR Algorithm
sections.text: DPOP-based DBR (DPOP-DBR) solves the relaxed DCOPs P-k and P-k-k via the relaxed graph G-k = < LNk, Ek >. Thus, E-k = Ek and problem solving P-k means optimization over all the destroyed variables that have no edges in Ek. The DPOP-DBR solution phase uses DPOP [17], a complete inference-based algorithm consisting of two phases operating on a DFS pseudo-tree. In the dissemination phase, each agent, starting from the leaves of the pseudo-tree, projects its own variable and sends its projected utilities to the parent. These utilities propagate the pseudo-tree induced by G-k until they reach the root. The hard limitations of the problem can of course be dealt with during this phase by getting all the usage algorithms inconsistent with the parent's message where they are sent to the root of their child.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: In addition to the incomplete algorithms described in the introduction, researchers have also developed extensions to complete algorithms that trade solution quality for faster runtime. For example, complete search algorithms have mechanisms that allow the user to set absolute or relative error limits [13, 27]. Researchers have also worked on non-iterative versions of inference-based incomplete DCOP algorithms, with and without quality guarantees [20, 14, 16]. However, such methods are unable to refine the returned original solution. Finally, the algorithm that is most similar to ours is LS-DPOP [18], which works on a pseudo-tree that performs a local search. However, unlike D-LNS, LS-DPOP only works in a single iteration, does not change its neighborhood and offers no quality guarantees.

sections.heading: 7 Experimental Results
sections.text: We evaluate the state-of-the-art D-LNS framework against incomplete DCOP algorithms with and without quality guarantees, selecting representative search, inference, and region approaches. We select Distributed Stochastic Algorithms (DSA) as representatives of incomplete search-based DCOP algorithms, selecting Max-Sum (MS) and Bounded Max-Sum (BMS) as representatives of inference-based DCOP algorithms, and k- and t-optimal algorithms (KOPT and TOPT) as representatives of region-based DCOP methods. All algorithms are based on their performance and popularity. We use the following implementations: We use the FRODNS framework [11] to evaluate MS and DSA, 9 the authoring code of BMS [20], and the DALO framework for KOPT and TOPT. We systematically evaluate the time we run the network.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a Distributed Large Neighborhood Search (D-LNS) framework that can be used to find quality-limited solutions in DCOPs. D-LNS consists of a destructive phase that selects a large neighborhood to search for, and a repair phase that performs the search across the selected neighborhood. We introduce two novel distributed repair phases, DPOP-DBR and T-DBR, that are built within the D-LNS framework and characterized by low network usage; in addition, T-DBR provides low computing complexity per agent. Experimental results show that the D-LNS algorithms quickly converge to better solutions, compared with incomplete DCOP algorithms that are representative of search, inference, and region-optimal approaches. The proposed results are significant - the ability of refining online quality guarantees, planning their fast-dependant configuration capabilities, and large-scale solutions to the D-based algorithms, the ability to deploy them in this class D, and the large-scale structures.
